description: From Middle English plesen, plaisen, borrowed from Old French plaise, conjugated form of plaisir or plaire, from Latin placeō (“to please, to seem good”), from the Proto-Indo-European *pleHk- (“pleasingness, permission”). Displaced native English queme (“to please, satisfy”), Middle English biluvien (“to please, delight”), Middle English liken (“to like, please”), Middle English lusten, listen (“to be pleasing, delight”).

verbs.description: please (third-person singular simple present pleases, present participle pleasing, simple past and past participle pleased)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make happy or satisfy; to give pleasure to.
examples: I'm pleased to see you've been behaving yourself.
Our new range of organic foods is sure to please.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, ergative) To desire; to will; to be pleased by.
examples: He doesn't think, he just says whatever he pleases.

description: Short for if you please, an intransitive, ergative form taken from if it please you which is a calque of French s'il vous plaît, which replaced pray.

entries.meaning: Used to make a polite request.
examples: Would you please sign this form?
Could you tell me the time, please?
May I take your order, please?
Give, please, directions to White House. (nonstandard usage)

entries.meaning: Used as an affirmative to an offer.
An expression of annoyance or impatience.
examples: Oh, please, do we have to hear that again?

description: Semantic loan from German bitte (“please; excuse me”).
